                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <p>An array  with key <code>links</code>.</p>
                  <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/links</p>
               </div>
            </div>
            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/links/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                     can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                     that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                     a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                     which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                     that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                     is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                     of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                     of the document containing the link.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/links/href">/assessment-plan/metadata/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/links/href</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">

            </div>
            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/id" class="toc4 head">id</h4>Role IdentifierA unique identifier for a specific role instance. This identifier's
                     uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same role across
                     minor revisions of the document.OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for
                     consistent use in OSCAL documents. This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer
                     specific semantics when these roles are used. These roles are documented in the specific
                     contexts of their use (e.g., responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such
                     a role, it is necessary to define these roles in this list, which will then allow
                     such a role to be referenced.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/@id"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/id">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/id</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Role Identifier</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>id</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/id</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A unique identifier for a specific role instance. This identifier's uniqueness is
                     document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same role across minor revisions
                     of the document.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for consistent use in OSCAL documents.
                           This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer specific semantics when these roles
                           are used. These roles are documented in the specific contexts of their use (e.g.,
                           responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such a role, it is necessary to define
                           these roles in this list, which will then allow such a role to be referenced.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="json-obj">

                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/title" class="toc4 head">title</h4>Role TitleA name given to the role, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/title"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/short-name" class="toc4 head">short-name</h4>Role Short NameA short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the role.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/short-name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>

               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/description" class="toc4 head">description</h4>Role DescriptionA summary of the role's purpose and associated responsibilities.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/description"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/description">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/description</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">

                     <p class="obj-name">string Role Description</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.markup-multiline">markup-multiline</a> with key <code>description</code>.</p>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props</p>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props/name" class="toc5 head">name</h5>Property NameA textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic,
                        or quality of the property's containing object.
                        
                        A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system.
                        An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated
                        value.

                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/role/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>

                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/roles/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/location/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props">/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props</p>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">

                     </div>

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or

                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/location/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/location/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props/ns">/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>

                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/location/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/locations/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>

            <section class="json-obj">

                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>

                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/party/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/party/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props/ns">/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/metadata/party/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/links/href">/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>

                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/metadata/parties/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                           <div class="remarks">

                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>

               <section class="json-obj">

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/metadata/responsible-parties/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.

                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

      <section class="json-obj">
         <div class="header">
            <div>
               <h2 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions" class="toc2 head">local-definitions</h2>Local DefinitionsUsed to define data objects that are used in the assessment plan,
               that do not appear in the referenced SSP.
               <p>An array of Component objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Component</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>components</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>Used to add any components, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR-&gt;AP-&gt;SSP)</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                           processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                           and/or privacy.</p>
                        <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                        <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                           component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Inventory Item objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Inventory Item</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>inventory-items</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A single managed inventory item within the system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>Used to add any inventory-items, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR-&gt;AP-&gt;SSP)</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of System User objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object System User</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>users</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A type of user that interacts with the system based on an associated role.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>Used to add any users, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR-&gt;AP-&gt;SSP)</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Permissible values to be determined closer to the application, such as by a receiving
                           authority.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Assessment-Specific Control Objective objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Assessment-Specific Control Objective</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>objectives-and-methods</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/objectives-and-methods</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A local definition of a control objective for this assessment. Uses catalog syntax
                     for control objective and assessment actions.</p>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Activity objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Activity</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>activities</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/activities</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Identifies an assessment or related process that can be performed. In the assessment
                     plan, this is an intended activity which may be associated with an assessment task.
                     In the assessment results, this an activity that was actually performed as part of
                     an assessment.</p>
               </div>RemarksAdditional commentary on the containing object.
               
               
               Since multiple component entries can be provided, each component must have a unique
               uuid.
               
               
               
               A given uuid must be assigned only once to a user.
               
               
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
            </div>
         </div>

                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/uuid" class="toc4 head">uuid</h4>Component IdentifierThe unique identifier for the component.

            </section>
            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/type" class="toc4 head">type</h4>Component TypeA category describing the purpose of the component.
                     
                     The system as a whole.
                     An external system, which may be a leveraged system or the other side of an interconnection.
                     A connection to something outside this system.
                     Any software, operating system, or firmware.
                     A physical device.
                     A service that may provide APIs.
                     An enforceable policy.
                     A tangible asset used to provide physical protections or countermeasures.
                     
                     A list of steps or actions to take to achieve some end result.
                     An applicable plan.
                     Any guideline or recommendation.
                     Any organizational or industry standard.
                     An external assessment performed on some other component, that has been validated
                     by a third-party.
                     
                     A physical or virtual network.

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props</a> in the object map.</p>

               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/component/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props/ns">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/component/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/links/href">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/responsible-roles/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.

                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/responsible-roles/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                           <h6 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/components/responsible-roles/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                           can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.

                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>

                        <div class="remarks">

                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href

                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using

                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items/responsible-parties/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>

                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>

                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.

                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered

                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                       OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                       or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                       and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                       an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                       lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                       consistency.</p>
                                    <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                       was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                       of the containing object.</p>

                              <h7 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/responsible-parties/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                              This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.

                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                    with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                 <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/user/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/user/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users/props/ns">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/local-definitions/users/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
