      <section class="json-obj">
         <div class="header">
            <div>
               <h2 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls" class="toc2 head">reviewed-controls</h2>Reviewed Controls and Control ObjectivesIdentifies the controls being assessed and
               their control objectives.Control Objective DescriptionA human-readable description
               of control objectives.
               <p>An array of Property objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/props</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Link objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/links</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Assessed Controls objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Assessed Controls</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>control-selections</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selections</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Identifies the controls being assessed. In the assessment plan, these are the planned
                     controls. In the assessment results, these are the actual controls, and reflects any
                     changes from the plan.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                        <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                        <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Referenced Control Objectives objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Referenced Control Objectives</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>control-objective-selections</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these
                     are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the assessed objectives,
                     and reflects any changes from the plan.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                           are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                        <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                           are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                        <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>RemarksAdditional commentary on the containing object.In the context of an assessment
               plan, this construct is used to identify the controls and control objectives that
               are to be assessed. In the context of an assessment result, this construct is used
               to identify the actual controls and objectives that were assessed, reflecting any
               changes from the plan.When resolving the selection of controls and control objectives,
               the following processing will occur:1. Controls will be resolved by creating a set
               of controls based on the control-selections by first handling the includes, and then
               removing any excluded controls.2. The set of control objectives will be resolved from
               the set of controls that was generated in the previous step. The set of control objectives
               is based on the control-objective-selection by first handling the includes, and then
               removing any excluded control objectives.
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
            </div>
         </div>
         <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls</a> in the object map.</p>
         <div class="obj-desc">
            <div class="obj-matrix">
               <p class="obj-name">object Reviewed Controls and Control Objectives</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <p>An object  with key <code>reviewed-controls</code>.</p>
               <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls</p>
            </div>
            <p class="description">Identifies the controls being assessed and their control objectives.</p>
            <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
               <summary>Remarks</summary>
               <div class="remarks">
                  <p>In the context of an assessment plan, this construct is used to identify the controls
                     and control objectives that are to be assessed. In the context of an assessment result,
                     this construct is used to identify the actual controls and objectives that were assessed,
                     reflecting any changes from the plan.</p>
                  <p>When resolving the selection of controls and control objectives, the following processing
                     will occur:</p>
                  <p>1. Controls will be resolved by creating a set of controls based on the control-selections
                     by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded controls.</p>
                  <p>2. The set of control objectives will be resolved from the set of controls that was
                     generated in the previous step. The set of control objectives is based on the control-objective-selection
                     by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded control objectives.</p>
               </div>
            </details>
         </div>

            <section class="json-obj">

                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/props/ns" class="toc4 head">ns</h4>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                     organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                     to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                     can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.

                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/links/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                     can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                     that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                     a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                     which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                     that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                     is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                     of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                     of the document containing the link.

                        <p>An object  member of array <code>control-selections</code>.</p>

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">Identifies the controls being assessed. In the assessment plan, these are the planned
                        controls. In the assessment results, these are the actual controls, and reflects any
                        changes from the plan.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                           <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code>, specifies all control identified in the <strong>baseline</strong> are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the <code>include-profile</code> statement within the linked SSP.</p>
                           <p>Any control specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via <code>include-controls</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selections/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selections/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selection/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selections/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selection/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selections/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-selections/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.

                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                        <p>An object  member of array <code>control-objective-selections</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these
                        are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the assessed objectives,
                        and reflects any changes from the plan.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                              are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>
                           <p>Any control objective specified within <code>exclude-controls</code> must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via <code>include-objectives</code> or <code>include-all</code>.</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The <code>include-all</code> field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls
                              are defined in the <code>control-selection</code>.</p>

                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.

                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/reviewed-controls/control-objective-selections/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>

                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using

                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.

                     <p class="obj-name">object Subject of Assessment</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>assessment-subjects</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Identifies system elements being assessed, such as components, inventory items, and
                     locations. In the assessment plan, this identifies a planned assessment subject. In
                     the assessment results this is an actual assessment subject, and reflects any changes
                     from the plan. exactly what will be the focus of this assessment. Any subjects not
                     identified in this way are out-of-scope.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Processing of an include/exclude pair starts with processing the include, then removing
                           matching entries in the exclude.</p>

         <section class="json-obj">
            <div class="header">
               <div>
                  <h3 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/type" class="toc3 head">type</h3>Subject TypeIndicates the type of assessment subject, such as a component, inventory,
                  item, location, or party represented by this selection statement.
                  
                  The referenced assessment subject is a component defined in the SSP, or in the local-definitions
                  of an Assessment Plan or Assessment Results.
                  The referenced assessment subject is a inventory item defined in the SSP, or in the
                  local-definitions of an Assessment Plan or Assessment Results.
                  The referenced assessment subject is a location defined in the metadata of the SSP,
                  Assessment Plan, or Assessment Results.
                  The referenced assessment subject is a person or team to interview, who is defined
                  as a party in the metadata of the SSP, Assessment Plan, or Assessment Results.
                  The referenced assessment subject is a user defined in the SSP, or in the local-definitions
                  of an Assessment Plan or Assessment Results.

         <section class="json-obj">
            <div class="header">
               <div>
                  <h3 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props" class="toc3 head">props</h3>
                  <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
               </div>
            </div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props/ns" class="toc4 head">ns</h4>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                     organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                     to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                     can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                     This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                     an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                     control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                     uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                     be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                     by the associated OSCAL model.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props/ns">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/props/ns</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/links/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                     can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                     that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                     a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                     which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                     that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                     is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                     of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                     of the document containing the link.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>

                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/links/href</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>

                     <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/name" class="toc5 head">name</h5>Property NameA textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic,

                     </div>
                  </div>

                  </div>
               </section>

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/uuid">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/ns">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/class" class="toc5 head">class</h5>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                        property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                        semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                        can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                        specific class value.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/prop/@class"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/class">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/class</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>class</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>

                           <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/links/href">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/include-subjects/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/include-subject/remarks"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/exclude-subject/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/name" class="toc5 head">name</h5>Property NameA textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic,

                     </div>
                  </div>

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or

                  </div>
               </section>

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/exclude-subject/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/uuid">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/exclude-subject/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/ns">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

               <section class="json-obj">

                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/class" class="toc5 head">class</h5>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                        property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                        semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class

                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/class">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/class</a> in the object map.</p>

                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subject/exclude-subject/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

      <section class="json-obj">
         <div class="header">
            <div>
               <h2 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-assets" class="toc2 head">assessment-assets</h2>Assessment AssetsIdentifies the assets used to perform this assessment, such as the
               assessment team, scanning tools, and assumptions.
               <p>An array of Component objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Component</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>components</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>Used to add any components for tools used during the assessment. These are represented
                           here to avoid mixing with system components.</p>
                        <p>The technology tools used by the assessor to perform the assessment, such as vulnerability
                           scanners. In the assessment plan these are the intended tools. In the assessment results,
                           these are the actual tools used, including any differences from the assessment plan.</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                           processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                           and/or privacy.</p>
                        <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                        <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                           component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Assessment Platform objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Assessment Platform</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>assessment-platforms</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/assessment-platforms</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Used to represent the toolset used to perform aspects of the assessment.</p>
               </div>
               
               
               Since multiple assessment component entries can be provided, each component must have
               a unique uuid.
               
               
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-assets"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
            </div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/type" class="toc4 head">type</h4>Component TypeA category describing the purpose of the component.
                     
                     The system as a whole.
                     An external system, which may be a leveraged system or the other side of an interconnection.
                     A connection to something outside this system.
                     Any software, operating system, or firmware.
                     A physical device.
                     A service that may provide APIs.
                     An enforceable policy.
                     A tangible asset used to provide physical protections or countermeasures.
                     
                     A list of steps or actions to take to achieve some end result.
                     An applicable plan.
                     Any guideline or recommendation.
                     Any organizational or industry standard.
                     An external assessment performed on some other component, that has been validated
                     by a third-party.
                     
                     A physical or virtual network.

                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/purpose" class="toc4 head">purpose</h4>PurposeA summary of the technological or business purpose of the component.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/component/purpose"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/props">/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/props</p>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/components/props/name" class="toc5 head">name</h5>Property NameA textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic,
                        or quality of the property's containing object.
                        
                        A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system.
                        An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated
                        value.
                        
                        
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/assessment-plan/assessment-assets/component/prop/@name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
